member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum unconsumed incoming bytes the server will buffer for incoming request body.

member.name: P:Microsoft.AspNetCore.Builder.IISServerOptions.ForwardWindowsAuthentication
member.summary: Used to indicate if the authentication handler should be registered. This is only done if ANCM indicates IIS has a non-anonymous authentication enabled, or for back compat with ANCMs that did not provide this information.

member.name: P:Microsoft.AspNetCore.Builder.IISServerOptions.MaxRequestBodySize
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum allowed size of any request body in bytes. When set to null, the maximum request length will not be restricted in ASP.NET Core. However, the IIS maxAllowedContentLength will still restrict content length requests (30,000,000 by default). This limit has no effect on upgraded connections which are always unlimited. This can be overridden per-request via .
member.remarks: Defaults to 30,000,000 bytes (~28.6 MB).

member.name: M:Microsoft.AspNetCore.HttpSys.Internal.RequestUriBuilder.DecodeCore(System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Int32,System.Span{System.Byte})
member.summary: Unescape the percent-encodings
member.param: The iterator point to the first % char

member.name: M:Microsoft.AspNetCore.HttpSys.Internal.RequestUriBuilder.UnescapePercentEncoding(System.Int32@,System.Int32,System.ReadOnlySpan{System.Byte})
member.summary:
Read the percent-encoding and try unescape it.
The operation first peek at the character the iterator points at. If it is % the is then moved on to scan the following to characters. If the two following characters are hexadecimal literals they will be unescaped and the value will be returned.
If the first character is not % the iterator will be removed beyond the location of % and -1 will be returned.
If the following two characters can't be successfully unescaped the iterator will be move behind the % and -1 will be returned.
member.returns: The unescaped byte if success. Otherwise return -1.

member.name: M:Microsoft.AspNetCore.HttpSys.Internal.RequestUriBuilder.ReadHex(System.Int32@,System.Int32,System.ReadOnlySpan{System.Byte})
member.summary:
Read the next char and convert it into hexadecimal value.
The iterator will be moved to the next byte no matter no matter whether the operation successes.
member.returns: The hexadecimal value if successes, otherwise -1.

member.name: T:System.Buffers.DiagnosticPoolBlock
member.summary: Block tracking object used by the byte buffer memory pool. A slab is a large allocation which is divided into smaller blocks. The individual blocks are then treated as independent array segments.

member.name: F:System.Buffers.DiagnosticPoolBlock._pool
member.summary: Back-reference to the memory pool which this block was allocated from. It may only be returned to this pool.

member.summary: This object cannot be instantiated outside of the static Create method

member.summary: Wraps an array allocated in the pinned object heap in a reusable block of managed memory

member.summary: Back-reference to the memory pool which this block was allocated from. It may only be returned to this pool.

member.name: T:System.Buffers.PinnedBlockMemoryPool
member.summary: Used to allocate and distribute re-usable blocks of memory.

member.name: F:System.Buffers.PinnedBlockMemoryPool._blockSize
member.summary: The size of a block. 4096 is chosen because most operating systems use 4k pages.

member.name: P:System.Buffers.PinnedBlockMemoryPool.MaxBufferSize
member.summary: Max allocation block size for pooled blocks, larger values can be leased but they will be disposed after use rather than returned to the pool.

member.name: P:System.Buffers.PinnedBlockMemoryPool.BlockSize
member.summary: The size of a block. 4096 is chosen because most operating systems use 4k pages.

member.name: F:System.Buffers.PinnedBlockMemoryPool._blocks
member.summary: Thread-safe collection of blocks which are currently in the pool. A slab will pre-allocate all of the block tracking objects and add them to this collection. When memory is requested it is taken from here first, and when it is returned it is re-added.

member.name: F:System.Buffers.PinnedBlockMemoryPool._isDisposed
member.summary: This is part of implementing the IDisposable pattern.

member.name: F:System.Buffers.PinnedBlockMemoryPool.AnySize
member.summary: This default value passed in to Rent to use the default value for the pool.

member.name: M:System.Buffers.PinnedBlockMemoryPool.Return(System.Buffers.MemoryPoolBlock)
member.summary: Called to return a block to the pool. Once Return has been called the memory no longer belongs to the caller, and Very Bad Things will happen if the memory is read of modified subsequently. If a caller fails to call Return and the block tracking object is garbage collected, the block tracking object's finalizer will automatically re-create and return a new tracking object into the pool. This will only happen if there is a bug in the server, however it is necessary to avoid leaving "dead zones" in the slab due to lost block tracking objects.
member.param: The block to return. It must have been acquired by calling Lease on the same memory pool instance.

member.summary: Provides support for efficiently using Tasks to implement the APM (Begin/End) pattern.

member.summary: Marshals the Task as an IAsyncResult, using the supplied callback and state to implement the APM pattern.
member.param: The callback to be invoked upon completion.
The state to be stored in the IAsyncResult.
member.returns: An IAsyncResult to represent the task's asynchronous operation.

member.summary: Processes an IAsyncResult returned by Begin.

member.summary: Processes an IAsyncResult returned by Begin.

member.name: T:System.Threading.Tasks.TaskToApm.TaskAsyncResult
member.summary: Provides a simple IAsyncResult that wraps a Task.
member.remarks: We could use the Task as the IAsyncResult if the Task's AsyncState is the same as the object state, but that's very rare, in particular in a situation where someone cares about allocation, and always using TaskAsyncResult simplifies things and enables additional optimizations.

member.name: T:System.IO.Pipelines.DuplexPipe
member.remarks:
A is a reader-writer pair, where content written to the writer can be read from the reader.
An is *not* a pipe. It is also a reader-writer pair, but the reader and writer are not connected. Rather, it can be regarded as *one end* of a two-way (i.e. duplex) communication channel, where content written to the writer is sent to the counterparty and content received from the counterparty is readable from the reader.
A is a pair of instances, each of which represents one end of a two-way communication channel. (In a sense, this makes it a "duplex pipe".) It can also be viewed as a pair of s, as these underlie the instances. In either view, it is composed of two s and two s - it is only how they are grouped that differs.

member.summary: Size, in bytes, of the range. If this member is HTTP_BYTE_RANGE_TO_EOF, the range extends from the starting offset to the end of the file or data block.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_COOKED_URL
member.summary: Contains a validated, canonical, UTF-16 Unicode-encoded URL request string together with pointers into it and element lengths.
member.remarks: For example, if pFullUrl is "http://www.fabrikam.com/path1/path2/file.ext?n1=v1&n2=v2", then pHost points to "www.fabrikam", pAbsPath points to "/path1/" and pQueryString points to "?n1=v1".

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_COOKED_URL.FullUrlLength
member.summary: Size, in bytes, of the data pointed to by the pFullUrl member, not including a terminating null character.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_COOKED_URL.HostLength
member.summary: Size, in bytes, of the data pointed to by the pHost member.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_COOKED_URL.AbsPathLength
member.summary: Size, in bytes, of the data pointed to by the pAbsPath member.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_COOKED_URL.QueryStringLength
member.summary: Size, in bytes, of the data pointed to by the pQueryString member.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_COOKED_URL.pFullUrl
member.summary: Pointer to the scheme element at the beginning of the URL (must be either "http://..." or "https://...").

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_COOKED_URL.pHost
member.summary: Pointer to the first character in the host element, immediately following the double slashes at the end of the scheme element.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_COOKED_URL.pAbsPath
member.summary: Pointer to the third forward slash ("/") in the string. In a UrlPrefix string, this is the slash immediately preceding the relativeUri element.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_COOKED_URL.pQueryString
member.summary: Pointer to the first question mark (?) in the string, or NULL if there is none.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_DATA_CHUNK
member.summary: Represents an individual block of data either in memory, in a file, or in the HTTP Server API response-fragment cache.

remarks.para: Learn more about this API from docs.microsoft.com.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_DATA_CHUNK.DataChunkType
member.summary: Type of data store. This member can be one of the values from the HTTP_DATA_CHUNK_TYPE enumeration.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_DATA_CHUNK_TYPE
member.summary: Defines the data source for a data chunk.

remarks.para: Learn more about this API from docs.microsoft.com.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_DATA_CHUNK_TYPE.HttpDataChunkFromMemory
member.summary: The data source is a memory data block. The union should be interpreted as a FromMemory structure.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_DATA_CHUNK_TYPE.HttpDataChunkFromFileHandle
member.summary: The data source is a file handle data block. The union should be interpreted as a FromFileHandle structure.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_DATA_CHUNK_TYPE.HttpDataChunkFromFragmentCache
member.summary: The data source is a fragment cache data block. The union should be interpreted as a FromFragmentCache structure.

summary.para: The data source is a fragment cache data block. The union should be interpreted as a FromFragmentCacheEx structure. Windows Server2003 with SP1 and WindowsXP with SP2:This flag is not supported.
The data source is a trailers data block. The union should be interpreted as a Trailers structure. Windows 10, version 2004 and prior:This flag is not supported.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_KNOWN_HEADER
member.summary: Contains the header values for a known header from an HTTP request or HTTP response.

remarks.para: In the HTTP Server API, known headers are defined as those that are enumerated in the HTTP_HEADER_ID enumeration type. Be aware that there are different lists of different sizes for request and response headers. For more information about the structure and usage of HTTP headers, see the RFC 2616.
Read more on docs.microsoft.com.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_KNOWN_HEADER.RawValueLength
member.summary: Size, in bytes, of the 8-bit string pointed to by the pRawValue member, not counting a terminating null character, if present. If RawValueLength is zero, then the value of the pRawValue element is meaningless.

summary.para: Pointer to the text of this HTTP header. Use RawValueLength to determine where this text ends rather than relying on the string to have a terminating null. The format of the header text is specified in RFC 2616.

member.name: P:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.__HTTP_KNOWN_HEADER_41.Length
member.summary: The length of the inline array.

member.name: M:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.__HTTP_KNOWN_HEADER_41.AsSpan
member.summary: Gets this inline array as a span.
member.remarks: Important : When this struct is on the stack, do not let the returned span outlive the stack frame that defines it.

member.name: M:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.__HTTP_KNOWN_HEADER_41.AsReadOnlySpan
member.summary: Gets this inline array as a span.
member.remarks: Important : When this struct is on the stack, do not let the returned span outlive the stack frame that defines it.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_INFO
member.summary: Contains the authentication status of the request with a handle to the client token that the receiving process can use to impersonate the authenticated client.

remarks.para: Starting with HTTP version 2.0, the HTTP_REQUEST structure contains an HTTP_REQUEST_INFO structure. The pVoid member of the HTTP_REQUEST_INFO structure points to the HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_INFO when the request information type is HttpRequestInfoTypeAuth. When the application receives a request with this structure and the request has not been authenticated, it can send the initial 401 challenge with the desired set of WWW-Authenticate headers in the HTTP_MULTIPLE_KNOWN_HEADERS structure. When the HTTP Server API completes the authentication handshake, it fills the HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_INFO structure and passes it to the application with the request again. The handle to the access token that represents the client identity is provided in this structure by the HTTP Server API. Context Attributes The ContextAttributes member is provided for SSPI based schemes. For example, SSPI applications can determine whether ASC_RET_MUTUAL_AUTH is set for a mutually authenticated session. The HTTP Server API does not provide the expiration time for the context in the PackedContext member. Applications may require the expiration time in specific circumstances, for example, when NTLM credential caching is enabled and the application queries for the expiration time for a cached context. If the server application requires the expiration time for the underlying client context associated with the access token, it can receive the packed context and call QueryContextAttributes with the SECPKG_ATTR_LIFESPAN. Mutual Authentication Data By default, the HTTP Server API ensures that the mutual authentication data is added to the final 200 response; in general, server applications are not responsible for sending the mutual authentication data. However, applications can receive the mutual authentication data and send it with the final response. When the ReceiveMutualAuth member of the HTTP_SERVER_AUTHENTICATION_INFO structure is set to true, applications receive the server credentials for mutual authentication along with the authenticated request. The mutual authentication data provided in the pMutualAuthData member contains the exact value of WWW-Authenticate header without the header name. For example, pMutualAuthData points to "Negotiate ade02938481eca". The application builds the WWW-Authenticate header by appending the provided pMutualAuthData as a response header value.
Read more on docs.microsoft.com.

summary.para: A member of the HTTP_AUTH_STATUS enumeration that indicates the final authentication status of the request. If the authentication status is not HttpAuthStatusSuccess, applications should disregard members of this structure except AuthStatus, SecStatus, and AuthType.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_INFO.SecStatus
member.summary: A SECURITY_STATUS value that indicates the security failure status when the AuthStatus member is HttpAuthStatusFailure.

summary.para: The authentication flags that indicate the following authentication attributes:

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_INFO.AuthType
member.summary: A member of the HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_TYPE enumeration that indicates the authentication scheme attempted or established for the request.

summary.para: A handle to the client token that the receiving process can use to impersonate the authenticated client. The handle to the token should be closed by calling CloseHandle when it is no longer required. This token is valid only for the lifetime of the request. Applications can regenerate the initial 401 challenge to reauthenticate when the token expires.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_INFO.ContextAttributes
member.summary: The client context attributes for the access token.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_INFO.PackedContextLength
member.summary: The length, in bytes, of the PackedContext.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_INFO.PackedContextType
member.summary: The type of context in the PackedContext member.

summary.para: The security context for the authentication type. Applications can query the attributes of the packed context by calling the SSPI QueryContextAttributes API. However, applications must acquire a credential handle for the security package for the indicated AuthType. Application should call the SSPI FreeContextBuffer API to free the serialized context when it is no longer required.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_INFO.MutualAuthDataLength
member.summary: The length, in bytes, of the pMutualAuthData member.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_INFO.pMutualAuthData
member.summary: The Base64 encoded mutual authentication data used in the WWW-Authenticate header.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_TYPE
member.summary: The HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_TYPE enumeration defines the authentication types supported by the HTTP Server API.This enumeration is used in the HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_INFO structure.

remarks.para: Learn more about this API from docs.microsoft.com.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_TYPE.HttpRequestAuthTypeNone
member.summary: No authentication is attempted for the request.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_TYPE.HttpRequestAuthTypeBasic
member.summary: Basic authentication is attempted for the request.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_TYPE.HttpRequestAuthTypeDigest
member.summary: Digest authentication is attempted for the request.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_TYPE.HttpRequestAuthTypeNTLM
member.summary: NTLM authentication is attempted for the request.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_TYPE.HttpRequestAuthTypeNegotiate
member.summary: Negotiate authentication is attempted for the request.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_TYPE.HttpRequestAuthTypeKerberos
member.summary: Kerberos authentication is attempted for the request.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_HEADERS
member.summary: Contains headers sent with an HTTP request.

remarks.para: Learn more about this API from docs.microsoft.com.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_HEADERS.UnknownHeaderCount
member.summary: A number of unknown headers sent with the HTTP request. This number is the size of the array pointed to by the pUnknownHeaders member.

summary.para: A pointer to an array of HTTP_UNKNOWN_HEADER structures. This array contains one structure for each of the unknown headers sent in the HTTP request.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_HEADERS.TrailerCount
member.summary: This member is reserved and must be zero.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_HEADERS.pTrailers
member.summary: This member is reserved and must be NULL.

summary.para: Fixed-size array of HTTP_KNOWN_HEADER structures. The HTTP_HEADER_ID enumeration provides a mapping from header types to array indexes. If a known header of a given type is included in the HTTP request, the array element at the index that corresponds to that type specifies the header value. Those elements of the array for which no corresponding headers are present contain a zero-valued RawValueLength member. Use RawValueLength to determine the end of the header string pointed to by pRawValue, rather than relying on the string to have a terminating null.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_INFO
member.summary: Extends the HTTP_REQUEST structure with additional information about the request.
member.remarks: Starting with the HTTP Server API version 2.0, the HTTP_REQUEST structure is extended to include an array of HTTP_REQUEST_INFO structures in the pRequestInfo member. These structures contain additional information for the request.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_INFO.InfoType
member.summary: A member of the HTTP_REQUEST_INFO_TYPE enumeration specifying the type of information contained in this structure.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_INFO.InfoLength
member.summary: The length, in bytes, of the pInfo member.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_INFO.pInfo
member.summary: A pointer to the HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_INFO structure when the InfoType member is HttpRequestInfoTypeAuth; otherwise NULL.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_INFO_TYPE
member.summary: The HTTP_REQUEST_INFO_TYPE enumeration defines the type of information contained in the HTTP_REQUEST_INFO structure. This enumeration is used in the HTTP_REQUEST_INFO structure.

remarks.para: Learn more about this API from docs.microsoft.com.

summary.para: The request information type is authentication. The pInfo member of the HTTP_REQUEST_INFO structure points to a HTTP_REQUEST_AUTH_INFO structure.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_PROPERTY
member.summary: Defines the properties that are configured by the HTTP Server API on a request.
member.remarks: The **HTTP\_REQUEST\_PROPERTY** enumeration types are used to set or query the configurations on a request. A member of this enumeration together with the associated configuration structure is used by [HttpSetRequestProperty](/windows/desktop/api/http/nf-http-httpsetrequestproperty) to define the configuration parameters.

summary.para: The HTTP/2 or HTTP/3 stream error on the request. The [HTTP\_REQUEST\_PROPERTY\_STREAM\_ERROR](/windows/win32/api/http/ns-http-http_request_property_stream_error) structure contains the configuration data for this property.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_V1
member.summary: Uses the HTTP_REQUEST structure to return data associated with a specific request.
member.remarks: The unprocessed URL contained in the pRawUrl member is for tracking and statistical purposes only. For other purposes, use the processed, canonical URL contained in the CookedUrl member.

summary.para: A combination of zero or more of the following flag values may be combined, with OR, as appropriate.
An identifier for the connection on which the request was received. Use this value when calling HttpWaitForDisconnect or HttpReceiveClientCertificate.
A value used to identify the request when calling HttpReceiveRequestEntityBody, HttpSendHttpResponse, and/or HttpSendResponseEntityBody.
The context that is associated with the URL in the pRawUrl parameter. Windows Server2003 with SP1 and WindowsXP with SP2:
An HTTP_VERSION structure that contains the version of HTTP specified by this request.
An HTTP verb associated with this request. This member can be one of the values from the HTTP_VERB enumeration.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_V1.UnknownVerbLength
member.summary: If the Verb member contains a value equal to HttpVerbUnknown, the UnknownVerbLength member contains the size, in bytes, of the string pointed to by the pUnknownVerb member, not including the terminating null character. If Verb is not equal to HttpVerbUnknown, UnknownVerbLength is equal to zero.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_V1.RawUrlLength
member.summary: The size, in bytes, of the unprocessed URL string pointed to by the pRawUrl member, not including the terminating null character.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_V1.pUnknownVerb
member.summary: If the Verb member is equal to HttpVerbUnknown, pUnknownVerb, points to a null-terminated string of octets that contains the HTTP verb for this request; otherwise, the application ignores this parameter.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_V1.pRawUrl
member.summary: A pointer to a string of octets that contains the original, unprocessed URL targeted by this request. Use this unprocessed URL only for tracking or statistical purposes; the CookedUrl member contains the canonical form of the URL for general use.

summary.para: An HTTP_COOKED_URL structure that contains a parsed canonical wide-character version of the URL targeted by this request. This is the version of the URL HTTP Listeners should act upon, rather than the raw URL.
An HTTP_TRANSPORT_ADDRESS structure that contains the transport addresses for the connection for this request.
An HTTP_REQUEST_HEADERS structure that contains the headers specified in this request.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_V1.BytesReceived
member.summary: The total number of bytes received from the network comprising this request.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_V1.EntityChunkCount
member.summary: The number of elements in the pEntityChunks array. If no entity body was copied, this value is zero.

summary.para: A pointer to an array of HTTP_DATA_CHUNK structures that contains the data blocks making up the entity body. HttpReceiveHttpRequest does not copy the entity body unless called with the HTTP_RECEIVE_REQUEST_FLAG_COPY_BODY flag set.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_V1.RawConnectionId
member.summary: Raw connection ID for an Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) request.

summary.para: A pointer to an HTTP_SSL_INFO structure that contains Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) information about the connection on which the request was received.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_V2
member.summary: Extends the HTTP_REQUEST_V1 request structure with more information about the request.

remarks.para: Learn more about this API from docs.microsoft.com.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_V2.RequestInfoCount
member.summary: The number of HTTP_REQUEST_INFO structures in the array pointed to by pRequestInfo.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_REQUEST_V2.pRequestInfo
member.summary: A pointer to an array of HTTP_REQUEST_INFO structures that contains additional information about the request.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_SSL_CLIENT_CERT_INFO
member.summary: Contains data about a Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) client certificate that can be used to determine whether the certificate is valid.

remarks.para: An HTTP_SSL_CLIENT_CERT_INFO structure is pointed to by the pClientCertInfo member of the HTTP_SSL_INFO structure, and is used by the HttpReceiveClientCertificate function to return data about the client certificate through the pSslClientCertInfo parameter.
Read more on docs.microsoft.com.

summary.para: Flags that indicate whether the certificate is valid. The possible values for this member are a SSPI Status Code returned from SSPI or one of the following flags from the dwError member of the CERT_CHAIN_POLICY_STATUS structure:

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_SSL_CLIENT_CERT_INFO.CertEncodedSize
member.summary: The size, in bytes, of the certificate.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_SSL_CLIENT_CERT_INFO.pCertEncoded
member.summary: A pointer to the actual certificate.

summary.para: A handle to an access token. If the HTTP_SERVICE_CONFIG_SSL_FLAG_USE_DS_MAPPER flag is set using the HttpSetServiceConfiguration function, and the client certificate was successfully mapped to an operating-system user account, then this member contains the handle to a valid access token. When the HTTP_SSL_CLIENT_CERT_INFO structure is no longer required, release this token explicitly by closing the handle.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_SSL_CLIENT_CERT_INFO.CertDeniedByMapper
member.summary: Reserved.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_SSL_INFO
member.summary: Contains data for a connection that uses Secure Sockets Layer (SSL), obtained through the SSL handshake.

remarks.para: An HTTP_SSL_INFO structure can be pointed to by the pSslInfo member of an HTTP_REQUEST structure.
Read more on docs.microsoft.com.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_SSL_INFO.ServerCertKeySize
member.summary: The size, in bytes, of the public key used to sign the server certificate.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_SSL_INFO.ConnectionKeySize
member.summary: The size, in bytes, of the cipher key used to encrypt the current session.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_SSL_INFO.ServerCertIssuerSize
member.summary: The size, in bytes, of the string pointed to by the pServerCertIssuer member not including the terminating null character.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_SSL_INFO.ServerCertSubjectSize
member.summary: The size, in bytes, of the string pointed to by the pServerCertSubject member not including the terminating null character.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_SSL_INFO.pServerCertIssuer
member.summary: A pointer to a null-terminated string of octets that specifies the name of the entity that issued the certificate.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_SSL_INFO.pServerCertSubject
member.summary: A pointer to a null-terminated string of octets that specifies the name of the entity to which the certificate belongs.

summary.para: A pointer to an HTTP_SSL_CLIENT_CERT_INFO structure that specifies the client certificate.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_SSL_INFO.SslClientCertNegotiated
member.summary: If non-zero, indicates that the client certificate is already present locally.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_TRANSPORT_ADDRESS
member.summary: Specifies the addresses (local and remote) used for a particular HTTP connection.
member.remarks: Although the pRemoteAddress and pLocalAddress members are formally declared as PSOCKADDR, they are in fact PSOCKADDR_IN or PSOCKADDR_IN6 types. Inspect the sa_family member, which is the same in all three structures, to determine how to access the address. If sa_family is equal to AF_INET, then the address is in IPv4 form and can be accessed by casting the members to PSOCKADDR_IN, but if sa_family equals AF_INET6, the address is in IPv6 form and you must cast them to PSOCKADDR_IN6 before accessing the address. Both pLocalAddress and pRemoteAddress are always of the same type; that is they are either both of type PSOCKADDR_IN or both of type PSOCKADDR_IN6.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_TRANSPORT_ADDRESS.pRemoteAddress
member.summary: A pointer to the remote IP address associated with this connection. For more information about how to access this address, see the Remarks section.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_TRANSPORT_ADDRESS.pLocalAddress
member.summary: A pointer to the local IP address associated with this connection. For more information about how to access this address, see the Remarks section.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_UNKNOWN_HEADER
member.summary: Contains the name and value for a header in an HTTP request or response whose name does not appear in the enumeration.

remarks.para: Learn more about this API from docs.microsoft.com.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_UNKNOWN_HEADER.NameLength
member.summary: The size, in bytes, of the data pointed to by the pName member not counting a terminating null.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_UNKNOWN_HEADER.RawValueLength
member.summary: The size, in bytes, of the data pointed to by the pRawValue member, in bytes.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_UNKNOWN_HEADER.pName
member.summary: A pointer to a string of octets that specifies the header name. Use NameLength to determine the end of the string, rather than relying on a terminating null.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_UNKNOWN_HEADER.pRawValue
member.summary: A pointer to a string of octets that specifies the values for this header. Use RawValueLength to determine the end of the string, rather than relying on a terminating null.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_VERB
member.summary: The HTTP_VERB enumeration type defines values that are used to specify known, standard HTTP verbs in the HTTP_REQUEST structure. The majority of these known verbs are documented in RFC 2616 and RFC 2518, as indicated below.

remarks.para: Learn more about this API from docs.microsoft.com.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_VERB.HttpVerbUnparsed
member.summary: Not relevant for applications; used only in kernel mode.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_VERB.HttpVerbUnknown
member.summary: Indicates that the application can examine the UnknownVerbLength and pUnknownVerb members of the HTTP_REQUEST structure to retrieve the HTTP verb for the request. This is the case in an HTTP/1.1 request when a browser client specifies a custom verb.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_VERB.HttpVerbInvalid
member.summary: Not relevant for applications; used only in kernel mode.

summary.para: The OPTIONS method requests information about the communication options and requirements associated with a URI.

The GET method retrieves the information or entity that is identified by the URI of the Request. If that URI refers to a script or other data-producing process, it is the data produced, not the text of the script, that is returned in the response. A GET method can be made conditional or partial by including a conditional or Range header field in the request. A conditional GET requests that the entity be sent only if all conditions specified in the header are met, and a partial GET requests only part of the entity, as specified in the Range header. Both of these forms of GET can help avoid unnecessary network traffic.
The HEAD method is identical to GET except that the server only returns message-headers in the response, without a message-body. The headers are the same as would be returned in response to a GET.
The POST method is used to post a new entity as an addition to a URI. The URI identifies an entity that consumes the posted data in some fashion.
The PUT method is used to replace an entity identified by a URI.
The DELETE method requests that a specified URI be deleted.

The TRACE method invokes a remote, application-layer loop-back of the request message. It allows the client to see what is being received at the other end of the request chain for diagnostic purposes. See page 56 of RFC 2616.
The CONNECT method can be used with a proxy that can dynamically switch to tunneling, as in the case of SSL tunneling. See page 57 of RFC 2616.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_VERB.HttpVerbTRACK
member.summary: The TRACK method is used by Microsoft Cluster Server to implement a non-logged trace.

summary.para: The MOVE method requests a WebDAV operation equivalent to a copy (COPY), followed by consistency maintenance processing, followed by a delete of the source, where all three actions are performed atomically. When applied to a collection, "Depth" is assumed to be or must be specified as "infinity". See page 42 of RFC 2518.

The COPY method requests a WebDAV operation that creates a duplicate of the source resource, identified by the Request URI, in the destination resource, identified by a URI specified in the Destination header. See page 37 of RFC 2518.
The PROPFIND method requests a WebDAV operation that retrieves properties defined on the resource identified by the Request-URI. See page 24 of RFC 2518.
The PROPPATCH method requests a WebDAV operation that sets and/or removes properties defined on the resource identified by the Request-URI. See page 31 of RFC 2518.
The MKCOL method requests a WebDAV operation that creates a new collection resource at the location specified by the Request-URI. See page 33 of RFC 2518.
The LOCK method requests a WebDAV operation that creates a lock as specified by the lockinfo XML element on the Request-URI. See page 45 of RFC 2518.

The UNLOCK method requests a WebDAV operation that removes a lock, identified by a lock token in the Lock-Token request header, from the resource identified by the Request-URI, and from all other resources included in the lock. See page 51 of RFC 2518.

The SEARCH method requests a WebDAV operation used by Microsoft Exchange to search folders. See the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) Internet Draft WebDAV SEARCH for more information, and the WebDAV Web site for possible updates.

member.name: F:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_VERB.HttpVerbMaximum
member.summary: Terminates the enumeration; is not used to define a verb.

member.name: T:Windows.Win32.Networking.HttpServer.HTTP_VERSION
member.summary: Defines a version of the HTTP protocol that a request requires or a response provides.

remarks.para:
For more information about the HTTP protocol, see RFC 2616. The following macros define various versions of the HTTP protocol:"#define HTTP_VERSION_UNKNOWN { 0, 0 }""#define HTTP_VERSION_0_9 { 0, 9 }""#define HTTP_VERSION_1_0 { 1, 0 }""#define HTTP_VERSION_1_1 { 1, 1 }" The HTTP Server API provides a number of macros that can be used to evaluate the value of an HTTP_VERSION structure; For more information, see HTTP Server API Version 1.0 Macros.
NoteThe HTTP Server API rejects a version of HTTP larger than 65,535 in either the major or minor portion. If a request includes such a version number, the HTTP Server API discards it and returns a response with status 400 ("Bad Request").
Read more on docs.microsoft.com.

member.remarks: Important : When this struct is on the stack, do not let the returned span outlive the stack frame that defines it.

remarks.para: The **HRESULT** data type is the same as the [SCODE](scode.md) data type. An **HRESULT** value consists of the following fields: - A 1-bit code indicating severity, where zero represents success and 1 represents failure. - A 4-bit reserved value. - An 11-bit code indicating responsibility for the error or warning, also known as a facility code. - A 16-bit code describing the error or warning. Most MAPI interface methods and functions return **HRESULT** values to provide detailed cause formation. **HRESULT** values are also used widely in OLE interface methods. OLE provides several macros for converting between **HRESULT** values and **SCODE** values, another common data type for error handling. > [!NOTE] > In 64-bit MAPI, **HRESULT** is still a 32-bit value. For information about the OLE use of **HRESULT** values, see the *OLE Programmer's Reference*. For more information about the use of these values in MAPI, see [Error Handling](error-handling-in-mapi.md) and any of the following interface methods: [IABLogon::GetLastError](iablogon-getlasterror.md) [IMAPISupport::GetLastError](imapisupport-getlasterror.md) [IMAPIControl::GetLastError](imapicontrol-getlasterror.md) [IMAPITable::GetLastError](imapitable-getlasterror.md) [IMAPIProp::GetLastError](imapiprop-getlasterror.md) [IMAPIViewAdviseSink::OnPrint](imapiviewadvisesink-onprint.md)
Read more on docs.microsoft.com.

member.name: M:Windows.Win32.Foundation.HRESULT.ThrowOnFailure(System.IntPtr)
member.param: A pointer to the IErrorInfo interface that provides more information about the error. You can specify to use the current IErrorInfo interface, or new IntPtr(-1) to ignore the current IErrorInfo interface and construct the exception just from the error code.
member.returns: , if it does not reflect an error.

member.name: M:Windows.Win32.PInvoke.CloseHandle(Windows.Win32.Foundation.HANDLE)
member.summary: Closes an open object handle.
member.param: A valid handle to an open object.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError. If the application is running under a debugger, the function will throw an exception if it receives either a handle value that is not valid or a pseudo-handle value. This can happen if you close a handle twice, or if you call CloseHandle on a handle returned by the FindFirstFile function instead of calling the FindClose function.

remarks.para: The CloseHandle function closes handles to the following objects:
This doc was truncated.
Read more on docs.microsoft.com.
